channel.title: Culture – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: The Distance: Translating between Texts and Territories
item.dc:creator: Tommaso Manfredini
item.description: The recent essays on canon formation and literary aesthetics raise a vital question about the tension between faithful and successful translations. I see these essays as a twofold project: not only are they concerned with practices of translation and processes of canon formation on the “target” side, but they also have to account for the … Continue reading The Distance: Translating between Texts and Territories →

item.title: Teaching Notes: “Name that Fictional Muslim Character”
item.dc:creator: Sahar Ullah
item.description: Teaching Notes Mid-semester, I asked my Contemporary Islamic Civilizations section* to write down the first thing that pops in their mind when I say, “Name a fictional Muslim character.” I gave the students a minute, collected the names and then read them out loud.This is what they wrote (and how they wrote it): Aladdin: 4 … Continue reading Teaching Notes: “Name that Fictional Muslim Character” →

item.title: Antonio de Sosa’s Moors/Moros in ‘Topography of Algiers’
item.dc:creator: Sahar Ullah
item.description: In Covarrubia’s seventeenth century dictionary Tesoro de La Lengua Castellana O Española, moro (from the Latin Maurus) is defined as “one from the province of Mauritania.” The term is meant to be used pejoratively as in the proverb, “A Moro muerto, gran lanzada” (p.1150). The Real Academia Española offers more than eleven definitions, including the … Continue reading Antonio de Sosa’s Moors/Moros in ‘Topography of Algiers’ →

item.title: Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check
item.dc:creator: Chantal James
item.description: This July Morocco celebrated Throne Day, in celebration of King Mohammed VI’s ascension to the throne thirteen years ago. He seems to have much to celebrate; time and again, the crown asserts itself as secure against threats large and small. What has been the Moroccan monarchy’s secret to maintaining power in a post-Bouazizi world, when … Continue reading Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check →

item.title: Persian, Indo-Persian, and Homeless Texts
item.dc:creator: Arthur Dudney
item.description: He caught up with me as I turned the corner in Connaught Place (C.P.), the shopping hub in central Delhi where I had been running some errands. He was fair-skinned and wearing a checked shirt, jeans and bright sneakers–the basic uniform of young men in urban India. He was probably one of the Kashmiris … Continue reading Persian, Indo-Persian, and Homeless Texts →
